titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Ernest Schelling papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by David Jacobs and Sarah Patton

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2016-03-15T12:55-0700
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

change.item: Declassified records series and description of incremental materials (boxes 8-13) added to collection by Sarah Patton.

did.abstract: The Ernest Schelling papers largely consist of printed matter, photographs, and memorabilia, much of it relating to Schelling’s service as a major in the United States Army during World War I and as an assistant military attaché in Switzerland during and immediately after that war. The papers also contain materials pertaining to Schelling’s long career as a classical pianist and conductor, and especially to his friendship with the Polish musician and statesman, Ignace (Ignacy) Paderewski. There is some personal correspondence in the collection, as well as correspondence belonging to Lucie (Lucy) Schelling (Ernest Schelling’s first wife) and Helen “Peggy” Schelling (his second wife and widow).

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Ernest Schelling papers, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 2012 from the family of Schelling's second wife, Helen "Peggy" Marshall, later Mrs. Helen Scholz, with incremental material received later.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Ernest Schelling collection, International Piano Archives, University of Maryland

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Orders, Decorations and Insignia, Military and Civil; With the History and Romance of Their Origin and a Full Description of Each, Robert Wyllie, 1921, given to Hoover Library.

chronitem.event: Began studying piano with Ignace Paderewski
Commissioned as major in the United States Army
Served as assistant military attaché, American Legation, Berne, Switzerland
Conductor, Young People's Concerts of the New York Philharmonic Symphonic Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Ernest Schelling papers largely consist of printed matter, photographs, and memorabilia, much of it relating to Schelling’s service as a major in the United States Army during World War I and as an assistant military attaché in Switzerland during and immediately after that war. The World War I materials include copies of American government publications relating to military affairs, clippings, serial issues, and numerous photographs depicting soldiers of the American Expeditionary Forces in action in France and Germany. There are also copies of proclamations issued by the German military in occupied Belgium. In addition, the papers contain Schelling’s translation of one volume of the official German history of World War I. Official and personal correspondence, memoranda, reports, printed matter, and other materials relating to Schelling's service as an assistant military attaché can also be found in the Incremental Materials (Boxes 8-13).

Also included in the collection are materials pertaining to Schelling’s long career as a classical pianist and conductor, and especially to his friendship with the Polish musician and statesman, Ignace (Ignacy) Paderewski. There are photographs of Paderewski, including ones from his childhood, as well as programs relating to concert performances by Paderewski.

There is also some personal correspondence in the collection, as well as correspondence belonging to Lucie (Lucy) Schelling (Ernest Schelling’s first wife) and Helen “Peggy” Schelling (his second wife and widow). The collection also contains significant memorabilia, including various awards received by Schelling, as well as his World War I army uniform.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes an inscription by Taft: "For Mr. Ernest Schelling with grateful appreciation of the wonderful music drawn from the piano he gave us at the White House February 7th 1913."

did.unittitle: Print of portrait of Friedrich Wilhelm Joseph von Schelling (German philosopher),
Proclamations issued by the German army in Belgium and France,
Framed display of medals awarded to Ernest Schelling,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes the Ordre National de la Légion d’honneur; the Order Odrodzenia Polski, Polonia Restituta; the Ordre du Saint-Sépulcre Orthodoxe; and the Distinguished Service Medal.

did.unittitle: U.S. Army cap worn by Ernest Schelling,
U.S. Army jacket worn by Ernest Schelling,
Légion d'Honneur (Legion of Honor) medal and case,
Infantry Drill Regulations, United States Army,
Regulations of the Army of the United States,
Géographie des principales puissances du monde,
Gore, James Howard, American Legionnaires of France,
To Ignace Paderewski, Artist, Patriot, Humanitarian,
Pamphlets relating to American and German military policy,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, reports, printed matter, newspaper clippings, ephemera, address books, notebooks, passports, and photographs largely relating to Schelling's time as an assistant military attaché in Switzerland after World War I and his friendship with Ignace Paderewski, arranged alphabetically by subject or physical form. See "Key to military file" (Box 8, folder 1) for more information about the organization of the materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Handwritten and typed notes provided by a relative of Schelling's, detailing the organization of Schelling's papers. There is an item-level index indicating which items were found together under Schelling's original organizational scheme and then a cross-reference indicating which descriptive headings the items were put under. These latter headings are what were used as the folder titles for the Military file of the Incremental Materials, and any additional notes were added as Scope and Content notes, in quotation marks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes military identity cards, diplomatic passes and passports, certificates, travel documents, and summaries of Schelling's military activities/rankings and decorations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: From folders labeled "Major Schelling - Official," "Major Schelling - Official - Personal," and "Poland." Largely consists of correspondence and orders directly relating to Schelling's military duties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: From folder labeled "Military - Unofficial letters to Major Schelling." Largely consists of correspondence received by Schelling during his military career or from military colleagues unrelated to his duties or of a more personal nature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Lists of officials - Berne; official address book; M.A. ball - June 26, 1919."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Report of military attaché's office."

did.unittitle: Between the Schellings (Ernest, Lucie, Helen) and Paderewski/Paderewska,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters, notes, cables, telegrams, and postcards. With two exceptions, the postcards (1902-1904) are addressed to Madame [Helena] Paderewska from Ernest Schelling. The other two are addressed to Madame Jaszowska, Paderewska's aunt.

did.unittitle: Between Ernest Schelling and others re Paderewski

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The majority of the material relates to a Saturday Evening Post article, 7 April 1934, which disparaged Paderewski.

did.unittitle: Re Paderewski week (17-23 January 1937) and proposed Paderewski Fund,
Between Helen "Peggy" Schelling and others re Paderewski,
Between Lucie (Lucy) Schelling and others re Paderewski,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes RSVPs (acceptances and regrets) to 20 February 1921 reception for Paderewski at the Colony Club.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes handwritten notes regarding annoucement of funeral services at Arlington National Cemetery in 1941, invitation to a fifth anniversary mass in 1946, and a list of friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notes, receipts, press release, and summaries of information relating to Paderewski, Schelling, and other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Largely photographs of Paderewski and Schelling, but some group shots of Paderewski in domestic setting with others are included as well. See also: Boxes 1-2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: See also: Boxes 1-2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, notes, printed matter, press release, and program relating to Schelling and his legacy, the military, and Paderewski, received or collected by Schelling's second wife, Helen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, notes, and passports of Schelling's first wife, Lucie, as well as materials relating to her death and funeral.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of a cartoon, undated; a typescript draft of a concert program, undated; a zeppelin ticket, 1930; and a flyer for a piano recital by Claudette Sorel, 1960.

did.unittitle: Aubert, Maître, Bolshevism's Terrible Record: An Indictment, issued under the auspices of the Entente Internationale contre le IIIe Internationale,
Flynn, John T., The Road Ahead: America's Creeping Revolution,
Herzig & McLean, Inc., General Pershing's Story of the American Army in France,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprints General Pershing's 20 November 1918 report to the Secretary of War, as well as some World War I poetry.

did.unittitle: Novik, Dmitri, Théodore Aubert et Son Oeuvre: Le Mouvement International Contre le Bolchévisme, édition des Amis de l'Entente Internationale contre la IIIe Internationale,
Otto Ulbrich Co., Catalogue of United States Martial Short Arms,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Related to Schelling's support of music and his fellow musicians, particularly through the Musicians Emergency Fund.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly security-classified records of the U.S. government, released in full or in part. Arranged chronologically by date of release by Hoover, thereunder chronologically by date of creation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of documents relating to Schelling's work as an assistant military attaché in Berne, Switzerland after World War I:
"Synposis of Cables Between the American Minister, Berne, Switzerland, and the State Department, with Reference to McN.," undated.
Memorandum re the Czech delegation in Switzerland, undated.
Letter from Schelling to Colonel Van Deman, Chielf Intelligence Section, War College, Washington D.C., 2 March 1918.
"The Situation in Germany: An Interview with a German Officer in the Würtemberg Infantry (Engineer Corps), a Mining Engineer," 25 May 1920.
